# 3. Results

## 3.1 Participants and descriptive statistics

Data collection took place between `r format(as.Date(acqui_time[1]), "%Y-%m")` and `r format(as.Date(acqui_time[2]), "%Y-%m")`.
A total of $N=`r sum(data_survey[,"lay_beliefs_complete"] == 2)`$ participants completed the online survey and were invited to participate in the two lab sessions.
Of these, $N=`r sum(data_survey[,"files_coged_complete"] == 2)`$ participated in the first laboratory session [@ZernaScheffel2022] and $N=`r sum(data_survey[,"followup_ered_complete"] == 2)`$ completed the second laboratory session.
Of these, $n=1$ person had to be excluded from analyses because they did not follow the instructions.
The final sample consisted of $N=`r sum(data_survey[,"followup_ered_complete"] == 2)-1`$ participants (`r length(which(data_descr[which(data_descr[,"ID"] != dplyr::lag(data_descr[,"ID"])),"gender"] == 2))` female ; age: $M=`r papaja::printnum(mean(data_descr[,"age"], na.rm = TRUE), digits = 1, gt1 = TRUE)`\text{ }\pm\text{ }SD = `r papaja::printnum(sd(data_descr[,"age"], na.rm = TRUE), digits = 1, gt1 = TRUE)`$).
Please note that sample size for individual calculations may be smaller due to failure of EMG recording ($n=1$) and failure to record utility ratings ($n=`r sum(is.na(data_ER[,"utility"][data_ER[,"block"] == "3_distraction"]))`$).

## 3.2. Confirmatory analyses

### Manipulation checks

#### Subjective arousal and physiological responding

To explore whether negative pictures evoke emotional arousal, we conducted an ANOVA for the active viewing condition. 
We found a highly significant main effect of valence (`r papaja::apa_print(SubjArousalView_aov)$full_result`, `r papaja::apa_print(SubjArousalView_BF)$statistic`), indicating that negative pictures were perceived as more arousing than neutral pictures ($\eta_{p}^{2}=`r papaja::printnum(SubjArousalView_con[,8:9])`$, $BF_{10}=$`r papaja::printnum(SubjArousalView_con[,7], format = "e")`).
To explore the effect of valence on facial muscle activity(*Corrugator* and *Levator*), we conducted two ANOVA for the active viewing condition.
For *Corrugator* activity, we found a significant main effect of valence (`r papaja::apa_print(EMGCorrView_aov)$full_result`, `r papaja::apa_print(EMGCorrView_BF)$statistic`), indicating that negative pictures evoked greater *Corrugator* activity than neutral pictures ($\eta_{p}^{2}=`r papaja::printnum(EMGCorrView_con[,8:9])`$, $BF_{10}=$`r papaja::printnum(EMGCorrView_con[,7], format = "e")`).
In line with previously reported results, there was a significant main effect of valence for *Levator* activity (`r papaja::apa_print(EMGLevView_aov)$full_result`Â´, `r papaja::apa_print(EMGLevView_BF)$statistic`), indicating that negative pictures evoked greater *Levator* activity than neutral pictures ($\eta_{p}^{2}=`r papaja::printnum(EMGLevView_con[,8:9])`$, $BF_{10}=$`r papaja::printnum(EMGLevView_con[,7], format = "e")`).

To investigate whether ER strategies reduce emotional arousal, we conducted an rmANOVA comparing the subjective arousal ratings of four strategies (active viewing, distraction, distancing, suppression). 
We found a significant effect of strategy (`r papaja::apa_print(SubjArousalReg_aov)$full_result`, `r papaja::apa_print(SubjArousalReg_BF)$statistic`).
Post-hoc test showed significantly reduced subjective arousal after use of distraction ($\eta_{p}^{2}=`r papaja::printnum(SubjArousalReg_con[1,8:9])`$, $BF_{10}=$`r papaja::printnum(SubjArousalReg_con[1,7], format = "e")`), distancing ($\eta_{p}^{2}=`r papaja::printnum(SubjArousalReg_con[2,8:9])`$, $BF_{10}=$`r papaja::printnum(SubjArousalReg_con[2,7], format = "e")`), and suppression ($\eta_{p}^{2}=`r papaja::printnum(SubjArousalReg_con[3,8:9])`$, $BF_{10}=$`r papaja::printnum(SubjArousalReg_con[3,7], format = "e")`) compared to active viewing.
However, there were no significant differences between strategies (all $p>.05$).
To explore whether ER strategies reduce physiological responding, we conducted another two rmANOVA comparing *Corrugator* activity and *Levator* activity of four the strategies.
Regarding *Corrugator* activity, we found a significant main effect of factor strategy (`r papaja::apa_print(EMGCorrReg_aov)$full_result`, `r papaja::apa_print(EMGCorrReg_BF)$statistic`).
Post-hoc test revealed reduced *Corrugator* activity during distraction ($\eta_{p}^{2}=`r papaja::printnum(EMGCorrReg_con[1,8:9])`$, $BF_{10}=$`r papaja::printnum(EMGCorrReg_con[1,7], format = "e")`), distancing ($\eta_{p}^{2}=`r papaja::printnum(EMGCorrReg_con[2,8:9])`$, $BF_{10}=$`r papaja::printnum(EMGCorrReg_con[2,7], format = "e")`), and suppression ($\eta_{p}^{2}=`r papaja::printnum(EMGCorrReg_con[3,8:9])`$, $BF_{10}=$`r papaja::printnum(EMGCorrReg_con[3,7], format = "e")`) compared to active viewing.
There were no significant differences between regulation strategies (all $p>.05$).

#### Subjective effort of ER strategies

To investigate whether ER strategies require cognitive effort, we conducted an rmANOVA comparing the subjective effort ratings of four strategies (active viewing, distraction, distancing, suppression).
We found a significant effect of strategy (`r papaja::apa_print(SubjEffort_aov)$full_result`, `r papaja::apa_print(SubjEffort_BF)$statistic`).
Post-hoc test showed significant higher subjective effort for distraction ($\eta_{p}^{2}=`r papaja::printnum(SubjEffort_con[1,8:9])`$, $BF_{10}=$`r papaja::printnum(SubjEffort_con[1,7], format = "e")`), distancing ($\eta_{p}^{2}=`r papaja::printnum(SubjEffort_con[2,8:9])`$, $BF_{10}=$`r papaja::printnum(SubjEffort_con[2,7], format = "e")`), and suppression ($\eta_{p}^{2}=`r papaja::printnum(SubjEffort_con[3,8:9])`$, $BF_{10}=$`r papaja::printnum(SubjEffort_con[3,7], format = "e")`) compared to active viewing.
Moreover, we found significantly lower effort during suppression compared with distraction ($\eta_{p}^{2}=`r papaja::printnum(SubjEffort_con[5,8:9])`$, $BF_{10}=$`r papaja::printnum(SubjEffort_con[5,7], format = "e")`) and distancing ($\eta_{p}^{2}=`r papaja::printnum(SubjEffort_con[6,8:9])`$, $BF_{10}=$`r papaja::printnum(SubjEffort_con[6,7], format = "e")`).

## 3.3. Exploratory analyses
